	<recipe id="7">
		<title>WHOLE WHEAT BANANA PANCAKES</title>
		<yields>12 PANCAKES</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>all-purpose flour</item>
				<key>all-purpose flour</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>brown or white sugar</item>
				<key>brown or white sugar</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>baking soda</item>
				<key>baking soda</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>salt</item>
				<key>salt</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>nondairy milk (like almond)</item>
				<key>nondairy milk (like almond)</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>small</unit>
				<item>banana, mashed</item>
				<key>banana, mashed</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>Grapeseed oil</item>
				<key>Grapeseed oil</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>1 In a big bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt. Make a crater in the
middle and add the milk and mashed up banana. Mix that all together until there are no more
dry spots, but don’t go crazy. Mixing it too much will make your pancakes tough, so just chill
the fuck out sir mix-a-lot.
2 Now, you probably know what to do once the batter is done, but in case this is your first
time at the griddle, keep reading. Grab a skillet or griddle and heat it over medium heat.
Lightly grease the pan with some oil and pour some pancake batter onto the griddle for each
pancake you want. Cook the first side for about 2 minutes or until bubbles appear on top. The
bubbles mean your pancake has cooked through. Flip and continue cooking the other side for 1
to 2 minutes or until the pancake looks golden brown.</instructions>
		<modifications>This should be around .33 cup.</modifications>
	</recipe>
	<recipe id="10">
		<title>WHOLE WHEAT BISCUITS</title>
		<yields>8 BISCUITS</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>almond or other nondairy milk</item>
				<key>almond or other nondairy milk</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>apple cider vinegar</item>
				<key>apple cider vinegar</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>flour</item>
				<key>flour</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>baking powder</item>
				<key>baking powder</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>sugar</item>
				<key>sugar</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>salt</item>
				<key>salt</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/4</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>butter</item>
				<key>butter</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>1 Crank your oven to 425°F. Line a baking sheet with some parchment paper.
2 Mix together the milk and vinegar in a small glass and set it out of the way for a minute.
3 Sift the flours, baking powder, sugar, and salt together in a medium bowl. Crumble the oil
into the flour a TBL at a time using your fingers and break up into pieces a little bigger
than a pea. It should look kinda like coarse sand from a shitty playground, minus the broken
glass. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk mixture. Stir until a shaggy dough is
formed, but be careful not to over-mix because then you will have some tough biscuits. If it is
too dry to stick together, add a TBL or two of milk.
4 Turn the dough out on a floured surface and pat it into a roughly 8 x 5-inch rectangle about
1.5 inches thick. using the open end of a glass or biscuit cutter, cut out all the motherfucking
biscuits you can and put them on the baking sheet. You should end up with about 8.
5 Bake the biscuits until the bottoms are golden, 15 to 18 minutes. Let them cool for a
minute before digging in or go ahead and start the day by burning the fuck out of your taste
buds, you dumbass.</instructions>
		<modifications>flour is really similar to all-purpose flour in texture and taste but contains all the good bran
and germ stuff like you find in whole wheat flour. Basically, it is the shit. If you can’t find it, use whole wheat or
all-purpose instead.
 Yeah, don’t bitch. In the quest for a fluffy biscuit, it had to be done.
 This needs to be all opaque and solid like butter. If it is clear and runny because it is hot outside, this won’t
fucking work. Stick it in the fridge until it gets its act together.</modifications>
	</recipe>
	<recipe id="47">
		<title>WILTED GREENS</title>
		<yields>2 AS A SIDE</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>bunch hearty, dark, leathery greens like kale or collards</item>
				<key>bunch hearty, dark, leathery greens like kale or collards</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>olive or grapeseed oil</item>
				<key>olive or grapeseed oil</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>water</item>
				<key>water</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>clove</unit>
				<item>garlic</item>
				<key>garlic</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>lemon juice</item>
				<key>lemon juice</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>soy sauce or tamari</item>
				<key>soy sauce or tamari</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>1 Remove the tough stems and slice the greens into strips about 1 inch wide and 2 inches
long. You should aim for around 6 cup. This might seem like way too many greens, but they’ll
cook down to fucking nothing. Trust.
2 Grab a big wok or skillet and heat up the oil over medium heat. Add the greens and toss
them around until everything has a little oil on it and cook for about 30 seconds.
3 Add the water, garlic, lemon juice, and soy sauce and then keep tossing those greens around
so that it all cooks down. This shouldn’t take more than a minute and a half. Once all the
greens are wilted, turn off the heat and serve.</instructions>
	</recipe>
	<recipe id="177">
		<title>WORTH-THE-MESS SLOPPY JOES</title>
		<yields>6 REASONABLE SAMMIES, 4 IF YOU LIKE HUGE AND SLOPPY</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>olive oil</item>
				<key>olive oil</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<item>0.5 yellow onion</item>
				<key>0.5 yellow onion</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>red or green bell pepper</item>
				<key>red or green bell pepper</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>carrot</item>
				<key>carrot</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>finely chopped button or cremini mushrooms</item>
				<key>finely chopped button or cremini mushrooms</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>clove</unit>
				<item>garlic</item>
				<key>garlic</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>to 2 jalapeños, seeded and minced</item>
				<key>to 2 jalapeños, seeded and minced</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>soy sauce or tamari</item>
				<key>soy sauce or tamari</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>smoked paprika</item>
				<key>smoked paprika</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>ground cumin</item>
				<key>ground cumin</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>mustard powder</item>
				<key>mustard powder</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>cooked kidney beans</item>
				<key>cooked kidney beans</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>cooked lentils (about ¾ cup dried)</item>
				<key>cooked lentils (about ¾ cup dried)</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>tomato sauce</item>
				<key>tomato sauce</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>apple cider vinegar or lemon juice</item>
				<key>apple cider vinegar or lemon juice</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>4</amount>
				<item>or 6 whole wheat hamburger buns, split and toasted</item>
				<key>or 6 whole wheat hamburger buns, split and toasted</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>0 chop onion, bell pepper, and carrot
1 In a large skillet or wok, warm the oil over medium-high heat. Add the onion, bell pepper, and carrot and cook until they start to soften and the onion looks kinda translucent, about 4 minutes. Add the mushrooms and cook until the mushrooms start to soften up too, about 2 minutes longer.
2 Add the garlic, jalapeños, soy sauce or tamari, smoked paprika, cumin, and mustard powder and sauté until the mushrooms have released some of their liquid and everything is smelling fucking awesome, about 2 minutes.
3 Dump in the whole beans, lentils, tomato sauce, vinegar and bring that shit up to a simmer. Once everything is all warmed up, turn off the heat and taste that shit. Add more garlic, salt, spices—you know, flavor—if you think it needs a little extra something.
4 To serve, pile high on toasted burger buns with a side of celery seed slaw (from the BBQ Bean Sliders) or a Big-Ass Salad. End up with some leftovers? This also makes a thick but badass pasta sauce.</instructions>
		<modifications>You know what you can handle.
 Not like the mustard condiment, it's the kind you find on the spice aisle. No luck or don’t want to spend the cash? Sub in 1 tsp of prepared yellow mustard if you must.
 Or one 15-ounce can of beans, all rinsed and shit.
 No fucking clue how to cook lentils? See Basic Pot of Beans.
 One 15-ounce can of tomato sauce is cool here.</modifications>
	</recipe>
	<recipe id="46">
		<title>YELLOW SPLIT PEA AND GREEN ONION LETTUCE WRAPS</title>
		<yields>12 TO 14 LETTUCE WRAPS</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>yellow split peas</item>
				<key>yellow split peas</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>3</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>water</item>
				<key>water</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<item>Salt</item>
				<key>Salt</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>soy sauce or tamari</item>
				<key>soy sauce or tamari</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>

			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>

				<key>rice vinegar</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1-2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>of your favorite Asian-style hot sauce</item>
				<key>of your favorite Asian-style hot sauce</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>toasted sesame oil</item>
				<key>toasted sesame oil</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>of your favorite liquid sweetener</item>
				<key>of your favorite liquid sweetener</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>neutral-tasting oil</item>
				<key>neutral-tasting oil</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1/2</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>shallots or yellow onion</item>
				<key>shallots or yellow onion</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>minced fresh ginger</item>
				<key>minced fresh ginger</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>minced green onions</item>
				<key>minced green onions</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2/3</amount>
				<unit>cup</unit>
				<item>shredded carrot</item>
				<key>shredded carrot</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>3</amount>
				<unit>TBL</unit>
				<item>rice vinegar</item>
				<key>rice vinegar</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>soy sauce or tamari</item>
				<key>soy sauce or tamari</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1 1/2</amount>
				<unit>tsp</unit>
				<item>toasted sesame oil</item>
				<key>toasted sesame oil</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>head of lettuce such as romaine or red leaf</item>
				<key>head of lettuce such as romaine or red leaf</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>1 Rinse the peas well and then throw them in a medium pot with the water and a pinch of salt
and bring them to a boil. Reduce the heat and let those sons of bitches simmer until they are
tender, 10 to 15 minutes. You can figure that shit out just by tasting them. When the peas are
done, drain them and set aside.
2 While the peas are cooking, mix together all the ingredients for the dipping sauce in a small
bowl.
3 Grab a big wok or skillet and heat the oil over medium heat. Add the shallots and sauté
until they start to turn golden, about 3 minutes. Add the ginger and green onions and let it all
cook together for another 30 seconds. Add the split peas and carrots, toss, then add the rice
vinegar and soy sauce. Let that simmer together for another 30 seconds while you stir. Add the
toasted sesame oil and then turn off the heat.
4 Serve the filling warm or at room temperature with a bunch of lettuce leaves to use as leafy
tortillas. Keep the dipping sauce on the side. Looks like a good fucking time.</instructions>
		<modifications>Optional but you really should try new shit.
 Agave or maple syrup would do if that’s what you’ve got.
 Use your box grater.</modifications>
	</recipe>
	<recipe id="161">
		<title>ZUCCHINI ROLLUPS</title>
		<yields>18 TO 24, DEPENDING ON THE SIZE OF YOUR ZUCCHINI</yields>
		<ingredient-list>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>3</amount>
				<unit>medium</unit>
				<item>zucchini</item>
				<key>zucchini</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<item>Creamy Pesto Dip</item>
				<key>Creamy Pesto Dip</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<item>carrots, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</item>
				<key>carrots, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>cucumber, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</item>
				<key>cucumber, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>1</amount>
				<item>red bell pepper, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</item>
				<key>red bell pepper, cut into 2-inch matchsticks</key>
			</ingredient>
			<ingredient>
				<amount>2</amount>
				<item>green onions, cut into thin strips, or a handful of chives</item>
				<key>green onions, cut into thin strips, or a handful of chives</key>
			</ingredient>
		</ingredient-list>
		<instructions>1 Chop the ends off of your zucchini so they are about the same length. Use a wide vegetable peeler or a sharp knife to cut wide planks of the zucchini lengthwise. Think lasagna noodle for the shape and the thickness, but a little thinner is cool, too. You should get 7 or 8 from each, depending on the zucchini.
2 Now to assemble those motherfuckers. Lay a plank of zucchini down with a short end toward you. Add 1 TBL of the pesto dip to the one-third of the plank closest to you. Add a few matchsticks of the veggies and the onions on top of your dip, perpendicular to the plank, keeping them even with one side of the zucchini and letting all the extra hang out on the other damn side. Roll it up away from you and stick a toothpick through it to hold it together and make a nice handle for people to grab the fucker with. Keep going until you run out of dip, zucchini, or goddamn patience.
3 Serve them right away or let them chill in the fridge, covered, for up to 2 hours before serving.</instructions>
	</recipe>
</gourmetDoc>
